h i g h l i g h t s
NS increases strength due to dense CSH gel mostly less than 5%. A small dosage of NS enhances the abrasion resistant. Using NS leads to the reduction of chloride ions penetration. Addition of NS to cement matrix improves the electrical resistivity. The incorporation of NS can increase the extent of shrinkage.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 16 January 2018 Received in revised form 30 April 2018 Accepted 30 May 2018 Available online 11 June 2018
Keywords: Nano-SiO2 Concrete Durability Mechanical properties Penetration Microstructure Resistivity
a b s t r a c t
Long-term durability of concrete has been of interest for researchers in past decades, and throughout their numerous research endeavors, they have tried to improve durability with the application of different methods. One technique is the integration of a new material into the concrete. One material that has attracted great attention of researchers is nano-SiO2 (NS). Its considerable performance in the enhancement of durability properties of concrete and mortar provides reasonable specifications satisfaction for scholars. In this paper, important durability characteristics of concrete, including the chloride ion penetration, electrical resistivity, water penetration, water absorption, the pore size distribution, the carbonation, the sulfate resistance, frost resistance, shrinkage, and thermal properties were explored. Additionally, the effects on the microstructure of concrete and mortar in the previous studies were discussed. Mechanical properties, such as compressive strength, flexural strength, tensile strength, and abrasion resistivity were also investigated in the past and most recent papers.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Over the past few years, durability properties of cement-based products have attracted the attention of researchers more than their mechanical properties. In fact, an essential step for an enhancement in serviceability of different types of concrete structures is the improvement of their durability. There is a great inclination among designers for inclusion of new materials, which can be an excellent substitute for traditional materials in the production of a more durable concrete. Nano-material is one of the most effective materials, making a great contribution to the durability properties of mortar and concrete [1].
The main progress in concrete performance was attained by the application of super-fine particles. The optimal performance of these systems was attributed to the high-density continuous packings of the binder constituents, as shown in Fig. 1 [2]. Using these fine particles in mix-design will cause high fluidity levels. Nanosilica (NS) was found to be a very effective additive to concrete for improving strength, flexibility, and durability. NS can be used as an additive to improve workability and the strength of highperformance and self-compacting concrete as well [3]. Nanobinders composed of nano-sized cementitious materials, pozzolanic nanoparticles and a finely ground mineral additivePortland cement mixture were proposed [4].
Based on a definition stated in 1981, a nano-material is considered to be a particle with dimensions between the interval of 1 and 100 nm. Nanoparticles play a major role in the improvement of
mechanical and durability properties of concrete by providing great specific surface area, which leads to acceleration of pozzolanic reactions. Productions of pozzolanic reactions contribute to densification of the concrete structure at a microscale by decreasing porosity of concrete and amelioration of interfacial transition zone (ITZ) properties. It also fills pores with nonreactive particles in the presence of cement. All these improvements positively affect the mechanical and durability characteristics of concrete and mortar [5–8]. Nano-materials, such as nanorice husk ash [8], nano-metakaolin [9], nano-TiO2 [10], nanoFe2O3, nano-Al2O3 were studied by different researchers because of their great performance in the improvement of concrete’s properties. However, the most common and important nano-material in the production of concrete is NS.
In recent years, NS has turned into an effective material for the improvement of mechanical and durability properties of concrete. These improvements lead to a longer lifespan of concrete structures and a reduction in cost for repair of such structures as a result. One of the main problems regarding the production of Portland cement is the high amount of greenhouse gas emissions that will be produced in the process of cement clinker manufacturing. The addition of NS to cement-based materials, because of its unique properties, not only can notably reduce the amount of required cement in the production of concrete, but also can prevent consumption of raw materials in this process.
Many attempts have been done regarding nanosilica incorporation in the concrete industry. Each research experiment
ea scale related to concrete materials [2].
investigated a part of this study and indicated NS effects on a few properties of concrete. However, a review that considers the simultaneous impacts of NS was needed to match the existing gaps. The significant parameters including NS fineness, NS replacement ratio, using other SCMs, mixture constituents and curing conditions have the most significant contribution to fresh, mechanical and durability properties of concretes with NS. So, the primary purpose of this study was to point out effects of these factors one by one and delineate how the future research should be oriented. Over 120 papers were reviewed and discussed in this paper.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Compressive strength
sections.text:
Nazari and Riahi [11,12] investigated the effect of 0–5% NS replacement on the compressive strength of high-strength compacting concrete with w/b ratio of 0.4. Their investigation revealed that an addition of NS up to 4% led to the increase of compressive strength and an increase in replacement level led to the reduction. However, it should be mentioned that 5% replacement of NS increased the compressive strength by more than 0%, 1%, 2%, and 3% replacement. They considered two reasons for the reduction of compressive strength with 5% replacement. First, as the NS crosses its beneficial threshold, there is not enough lime to react with and produce C-S-H gel during hydration. Thereby, excessive NS was replaced with cementitious materials while it cannot make a contribution to the enhancement of compressive strength. Second, a high amount of NS cannot be well-dispersed through the mixture due to agglomeration and as a result, cannot provide the best result. Li et al. [13,14], reported that 1% replacement of NS could enhance the compressive strength of pavement concrete more than one containing 3% or 5% NS. Moreover, they stated that nano TiO2 was more powerful in the enhancement of compressive strength in comparison to NS. The difference in optimal NS replacement in last two studies can be attributed to the difference in surface area of NS particles. Indeed, Li et al. (reference must be added) used NS with higher surface area. As such, there was a higher attraction force among NS particles and usage of higher NS percentage led to agglomeration of nano particles and inferior performance.
Sadrmomtazi et al. [15] reported that the optimum replacement level of NS is between 5% and 7%. Although any dosage higher than that of an optimum level increases the compressive strength in comparison to the control mixture, it does not do this by more than that of an optimum replacement level. Najigivi et al. It should be noted that Sadrmomtazi et al. (reference must be added) proposed higher dosage of NS replacement in comparison to other studies. The reason can be attributed to the fact that they used NS with average diameter of 50 nm. The higher average size of nano particles lead to less agglomeration; therefore, higher percentage of NS can be beneficial in enhancement of compressive strength. A group of researchers [16] observed that depending on curing in water or lime solution optimal NS replacement for the increment of compressive strength can slightly vary. If the concrete is cured in water, the threshold for NS replacement would be 1% and if it is cured in lime solution optimal replacement level would be 2% (see Fig. 2). They attributed this phenomenon to the presence of more Ca (OH)2 in a lime solution, which can react with NS particles and produce the C-S-H gel for further development of compressive strength. Riahi and Nazari [17] also mentioned that curing in saturated limewater could be more beneficial for increment of compressive strength in the presence of NS particles. Moreover, they observed that compressive strength of specimens made with NS
is superior to that made with nano-CuO. Some researchers believe that the increase of compressive strength by adding NS owes to the increase of C-S-H chains dimensions and stiffness [5]. The study of Wang et al. [18] demonstrated that 1% NS replacement could provide the maximal compressive strength for Ultra-HighPerformance (UHP) concrete. They observed that a replacement higher than 1% could lead to the reduction of compressive strength. They concluded that, owing to the agglomeration of NS higher than 1%, it can provide fewer nucleation sites for pozzolanic reaction, which produce the C-S-H gel and as result higher compressive strength. Another reason for increment of compressive strength mentioned by researchers is the improvement of ITZ. Indeed, the addition of NS improves the strength of ITZ by eliminating large pores in it. In addition, unreacted NS particles have a filler effect which can make the microstructure denser and more homogenous.
Elkady et al. [19] investigated the effect of the de-agglomeration process of NS on the compressive strength concrete. They observed that NS replacement up to 2% by weight of cement could enhance compressive strength by 7.3% in comparison to the control mixture. However, five minutes of sonication of NS before adding it to the concrete mixture will lead to enhancement of compressive strength up to 23% in comparison to the control specimen. Xu et al. [20] investigated the effect of colloidal NS modifications on ITZ at macro and micro scale at the age of three days. Throughout their modeling, at the macro scale, they concluded that incorporation of NS contributes to the enhancement of Young’s modulus of ITZ to Young’s modulus of bulk cement past ratio around 50%- 80%. However, at the micro scale, they observed that NS plays its major role by accelerating the hydration process and as a result, the ITZ at the early age of three days will be modified. These improvements in ITZ substantial increase the compressive strength. Ghafari et al. [21] showed that dispersion of NS within cement paste considerably govern its performance. Excess NS replacement causes agglomeration of particles within the cement paste; therefore, it leads to a weak zone and result in a compressive strength lower than that of optimal replacement.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Tensile strength
sections.text:
Parkasam et al. [22] measured split tensile strength of highstrength concrete made up of NS with 1% and 2% replacement levels. Their investigation revealed that tensile strength could improve up to 17% and 24% in comparison to the control mixture
by addition of 1% and 2% NS respectively (see Fig. 3). They also observed that this improvement mostly happened within a period of 28 days and at longer period, such as 56 days, no significant improvement was observed. They attributed this matter to poorly dispersed NS through the concrete matrix and also to a lack of Ca (OH)2 production at longer ages for further reaction with unreacted NS particles [23]. Jalal et al. [24] showed that incorporation of 10% fly ash and 2% NS with a different binder content of 400, 450, and 500 kg/m3 enhanced splitting tensile strength of self-compacting concrete by 25.6%, 30.7%, and 35.9% at the age of 90 days respectively.
As a tensile crack propagate inside the matrix of concrete, its leading edge usually consists of multiple microcracks, which join to form a macrocrack as the tensile displacement increase. Tensile strength is highly dependent on the tensile strength of the ITZ, the aggregate and the mortar. Low ratio of aggregate to ITZ strength lead to smooth fracture surface at failure and low tensile strength. On the other hand, high ratio of aggregate to ITZ strength results in rough failure surface and higher tensile strength. Nili and Ehsani [25], observed that in a plain concrete aggregate was surrounded by Ca(OH)2 and large pores were observed in SEM images. While incorporation of NS, excluded those large pores by reacting with Ca(OH)2 and converting it to C-S-H gel. As such, better bonding between aggregate and bulk cement paste was observed which can contribute to higher tensile strength [26].
Fallah and Nematzadeh [27] evaluated mechanical properties of high-strength concrete in the presence of macro-polymeric fibers and NS. Their investigation revealed that 1%, 2%, and 3% replacement of cement by NS enhanced tensile strength 12.96%, 7.82%, and 16.10% respectively. They attributed enhancement of tensile strength to the amelioration of bonding between cement matrix and aggregates. It is worth mentioning that they observed that 8%, 10%, and 12% replacement of cement by silica fume was more successful in the improvement of tensile strength. Low w/c ratio of high-strength concrete and tendency of NS to absorb more water due to its high surface area led to incomplete hydration reactions and decrement of tensile strength. Yet, a higher percentage of silica fume can be considered as one of the reasons for its better performance in comparison to NS. Ghazy et al. [28] assessed possibility of application of nano modified fly ash concrete as a repair material for concrete pavement. They observed that incorporation of 6% NS not only improved the tensile strength of specimens at longer ages but also improved it significantly at early ages. Thus, alongside durability properties, development of mechanical properties at early ages is an important criterion for repair materials.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Flexural strength
sections.text:
Experimental investigation of Rong et al. [29] revealed that incorporation of NS up to the threshold of 3% replacement could ameliorate flexural strength of UHP cementitious composites.
Study of Mohamed [30] showed that addition of 0.75% NS and 3% nano clay to concrete led to the enhancement of flexural strength up to 4% and 9% at the age of 90 days regarding the filler performance of nanoparticles. Moreover, it was observed that 3% nanoparticles replacement, which consists of 25% NS and 75% nano clay, provided the best result in terms of mechanical properties. Beigi et al. [31] studied the effect of incorporation of NS and fibers on mechanical and durability properties of self-compacting concrete. They observed the positive performance of NS alongside with fibers in the improvement of flexural strength. Fig. 4 demonstrates this improvement. Their study demonstrated that 4% replacement of cement particles with NS and 0.3% addition of steel fibers led to 76% increment of flexural strength in comparison to the control mixture. In addition to pozzolanic reactions, filler effect, reduction of Ca(OH)2 crystals, and nucleus performance, NS was considerably effective in the improvement of interfacial adhesion of cement matrix-fibers. A similar trend in improvement of compressive strength and flexural strength of concrete with the incorporation of NS particles is reported by researchers [30,32]. Li et al. [33], investigated the effect of NS and nano-TiO2 on flexural strength of pavement concrete. They observed that 1% replacement of nano-TiO2 slightly outperformed NS in enhancement of flexural strength. As they mentioned, this observation can be attributed to the much higher specific surface area of NS compared to nanoTiO2. Greater specific surface area can lead to harder dispersion of nano particles in the matrix. As such, weak zones form in the microstructure which can be the point for initiation and propagation of cracks and reduction in flexural strength.

sections.heading: 2.2. Abrasion resistivity
sections.text:
Several studies on the abrasion resistance of concrete pavement have been conducted. The results indicate that the abrasion resistance of concrete pavements is strongly affected by compressive strength, construction methods, curing conditions, material properties and testing conditions, i.e., dry or wet [34,35]. If concrete containing nanoparticles is used for pavement, the service life of pavement can be prolonged [13]. The abrasion resistance of concrete containing NS for pavement was experimentally studied. The test results indicated that the abrasion resistance of concretes containing nanoparticles is significantly improved. However, the enhanced extent of the abrasion resistance of concrete decreases with increasing content of NS particles more than the optimal replacement level. Sadegzadeh et al. [36] studied the surface microstructure and abrasion resistance of concrete. They found that different surface finishing methods produced diverse pore structures and hardness. Thus, the abrasion resistance of concrete mostly depends on the pore structures which can be improved
by the contribution of NS. Hui et al. [13] investigated the effect of NS, nano-TiO2, and polypropylene on abrasion resistance of pavement concrete. They found the abrasion resistance of concrete made up of nano particles is much higher than that of concrete made of polypropylene. Moreover, nano TiO2 particles were more favorable in the improvement of abrasion resistance in comparison to NS. They generally believe that NS particles can restrict the growth of calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)2) crystal, making the concrete matrix more compacted and homogenous. The authors also observed that 1% incorporation of NS could increase the enhanced extent of abrasion resistant by 157%. However, 3% incorporation of concrete could increase this value by 100.8%. Fig. 5 shows findings of this study. A possible explanation is that by increasing NS particles, the distance between these particles decreases. Less dispersive particles allowing more spaces for Ca(OH)2 crystal growth. This can lead to relatively weaker concrete matrix, and consequently less strength.

sections.heading: 2.3. Thermal behavior
sections.text:
Several studies have been conducted to investigate the thermal behavior of concrete in the presence of NS. It is widely accepted the NS can significantly improve concrete mechanical properties at high temperatures. Heikal et al. [37] studied the effect of substitution of 1% and 6% NS on the compressive strength at elevated temperature up to 1000 C for cement pastes containing blast-furnace slag. They observed a similar behavior for all cement pastes; the compressive strength increased as the temperature increased up to 450 C. Thereafter, the compressive strength dramatically decreased as the temperature reached 1000 C. This significant reduction at high temperatures was attributed to a possible decomposition of C-S-H phase, leading to an increase in porosity accompanied with significant decreases in the compressive strength. Their work generally showed that the substitution of NS slightly improved the resistance of cement pastes exposed to high temperatures. It is thought by researchers that NS can enhance the hydration of unreacted cement clinkers through internal autoclaving effect which forces the physically bound water to be available for internal curing at high temperatures. This mechanism can improve the hydration reaction of cement as well as the enhancement in the pozzolanic reactions of NS, which may eventually help in forming more C-S-H with low Ca/Si ratio to further strengthen the concrete matrix. Similar outcomes have been observed by Bastami et al. [38] in their investigation of the effect of elevated temperature on the mechanical properties of concrete containing both silica fume (SF) and NS (see Fig. 6). The total mass
for NS and SF was held constant at 30 kg/m3. The mixtures contained 1.41%, 2.83%, 4.2% NS (by mass of binder). The samples were heated at a rate of 20 C/min to temperatures of 400, 600 and 800 C. The data generally showed that the mass loss decreases as NS increases for specimens exposed to 400 C while an opposite behavior observed for specimens exposed to 600 C.
A thorough study has been conducted by Horszczaruk et al. [39], where they investigated the effect of elevated temperature (up to 800 C) on the mass loss, compressive strength and tensile strength of mortars containing 1%, 2%, 3%, 4% and 5% NS (% by weight of cement). The results showed a similar mass loss behavior for all mortars up to 400 C while a slight improvement was observed for mortars containing 3% and 5% NS in temperatures between 600 C and 800 C. The average mass loss was 3.7% and 4.5% in temperatures of 600 C and 800 C, respectively. For the compressive strength, the data showed that all mortars with NS had a higher strength compared to the reference sample. However, the sample with 3% NS exhibited a noticeable improvement in strength compared to other NS-based mortars. For the tensile strength, the authors concluded that the NS materials did not noticeably affect the tensile strength of the mortars because flexural strength is more sensitive to micro cracks caused by a build-up in vapor pressure. NS can react with lime to produce C-S-H gel which ameliorates the microstructure of the cement matrix and prevents cracks from propagating while the samples are exposed to elevated temperature. Ibrahim et al. [40] also studied the effect of high temperature on the mechanical properties of high-volume fly ash mortars containing NS. They showed that the addition of NS significantly improved both compressive and flexural strengths at temperatures up to 400 C. However, a significant reduction in strength was observed for all mortars at temperatures of 700 C. They believe that temperatures up to 400 C can increase the reactivity of NS, which in turn can produce more high-dense C-S-H to enhance the matrix strength; however, higher temperatures than 400 C can dehydrate cement hydrates and produce large crakes
due to the excessive of build-up vapor pressure, leading to weaker matrix and thus a significant reduction in strength.

sections.heading: 3.1. Chloride ions penetration
sections.text:
The intrusion of chloride ions into concrete can cause corrosion of buried rebar, followed by an abundance of cracks, and in the final stages, a detachment of the concrete from the rebar. As a result, assessing the permeability status of concrete and putting effort toward its improvement seems necessary. The Rapid Chloride Penetration Test (RCPT) was conducted by Said et al. [41] showed the replacement of 3% and 6% NS with cement particles could contribute to significant improvement in concrete permeability reduction. They stated that NS functions by refining the pore structure of the cement matrix. By their investigation, Du et al. [42] revealed that with 0.3% and 0.9% replacement dosages of NS, a better dispersion of this would be achieved. By adopting the Rapid Chloride Migration Test (RCMT), they observed that penetration depth, and consequently, the migration coefficient, would decrease considerably. Refinement of pore structure, specifically at the ITZ, as well as tortuosity and more disconnected transport channels, caused the reduction of permeability. One of the reasons that can be attributed to the huge difference between optimal replacement of NS. The form of the NS can explain the significant difference in Said et al. and Du et al.’s studies. Du et al. [42] used NS in powder form, which dictate the application of lower NS percentage in concrete. In contrast, Said et al. [41] used NS in aqueous form, which allow the researchers to use a higher NS percentage in the mixture due to less probability of nano particles agglomeration.
Through the investigation on the effects of NS on the permeability of self-compacting concrete by the RCPT, Mohseni et al. [43] demonstrated that a 5% dosage of NS could yield the best results in the reduction of a charge passed through a specimen. They observed that although 1% NS replacement could not improve permeability of specimens better than a range of moderate chloride permeability [44], its improvement is considerable in comparison to the control sample. Li et al. [45], studied the synergetic effect of NS and micro silica on microstructural properties of mortars. They observed that incorporation of these two materials caused formation of smaller voids and smaller crystals. Hence, the texture of microstructure was denser and more compact. Same as other studies, Quercia et al. [46] observed a reduction in the chloride migration coefficient of NS incorporated concrete. By analyzing the SEM images, Quercia et al. mentioned that the absence of crystallized portlandite and reduction in volume of gel pores confirmed refinement of microstructure by addition of NS. In addition, precipitation of small sized C-S-H gel was responsible for formation of dense microstructure [47,48]. Madani et al. [49], studied the influence of hydrosol NS on concrete, using both the RCMT and RCPT. Their research revealed that up to 3% replacement of NS had a slight effect on the reduction of passed charge through the specimens. However, in a close optimal replacement level to Said et al. [41], Madani et al. observed increasing the replacement level of NS to 5% notably reduced chloride intrusion into specimens. The results obtained by Said et al. are presented in Fig. 7. Similar to other researchers’ results, more blocked and tortuous routes would lead to a denser microstructure, thereby reducing chloride migration into concrete [50]. Moreover, they observed that an increase in specific surface area has notable effect on permeability. At a 3% replacement level of NS with specific surface areas of 300 m2/ g, 200 m2/g and 100 m2/g, reductions in passed charge of RCPT were 22%, 34%, and 50% respectively in comparison to the control mixture. They found that at the age of 28 and 90 days NS with lower specific surface area performed better than finer NS.

sections.heading: 3.2. Water absorption
sections.text:
Jalal et al. [51], observed that the incorporation of 2% NS decreased capillary water absorption by 58% in comparison to the control mixture without NS. Furthermore, they observed that the depth of absorbed water would decrease more notably at longer times of the test, such as 72 h. The samples’ pores were emptier at the beginning of the test due to being in the oven for an extended amount of time. Therefore, there is a great tendency for specimens to absorb more water. Tobón et al. [52], investigated the effect of NS on 3-days cured samples by 5% and 10% replacement levels. They observed that by the substitution of NS, the extent of absorbed water decreased significantly. High specific surface area and well-dispersion of NS can be considered for its power in the acceleration of pozzolanic reactions even at the age of 3 days. As they concluded in their research, the progress of NS pozzolanic reactions leads to the rupture of interconnected pores and the reduction of total pore volume, thereby inhibiting the amelioration of permeability [18]. It should be mentioned that Jalal et al. (reference must be added) used a w/b ratio of 0.38; therefore, lower percentage of NS were used in the mixture for acquiring desirable mechanical, durability and workability properties. On the other hand, Tobón et al. designed their mixture with w/b ratio of 0.55, which allowed the usage of higher NS percentage.
Chithra et al. [53], evaluated the influence of NS on durability properties of high-performance concrete with w/b ratio of 0.31. In a similar optimal replacement level to Jalal et al.’s study, Chithra et al. observed that small substations of cement by 2% NS would lead to a reduction of capillary water absorption. The efficiency of very fine NS particles, which blocking the pores and improving the microstructure of specimens, is another reason for the reduction of water absorption values. The influence of NS on ternary binders in concrete also has been studied by researchers [50,54]. Zahedi et al. [55], conducted a research project on the durability of concrete, which was made up of NS and rice husk ash. They reported that the water absorption of specimens that were only made with NS was remarkably reduced at early ages due to the high surface area of NS. The nucleation sites provided by NS helps the production of more C-S-H gel and as a result a denser microstructure. The addition of rice husk ash particles to NS influenced its effectiveness in the improvement of capillary water absorption at early ages. At the age of 28 days, 5 %NS + 10 %RHA outperformed the binary mixtures of NS and decreased water absorption by 28.1% in comparison to the control mixture (see Fig. 8).

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrical properties
sections.text:
Many researchers have shown that there is a strong relationship between the conductivity of concrete and its porosity, pore structure, and pH value of pore solution [56–60]. Generally, a high pH
of pore solution, a high degree of pore connectivity and low tortuosity lead to the high conductivity of concrete, which is an indicator of its high permeability. The most common test for assessing the conductivity and electrical properties of concrete is the Wenner four-electrode method [61,62]. Specifications, such as being a Non-Destructive Test (NDT), simplicity in use and short performance time made the Wenner a desirable device. The electrical resistivity of a specimen shows its resistance against penetration of aggressive ions. Thereby, an increase of electrical resistivity values is an indicator of improvement in terms of permeability [63].
Nili et al. studied the effects of NS and microsilica (MS) on concrete performance with 0.45 water-cement ratios. They used 1.5%, 3% and 4.5% NS as cement replacement percentages. A considerable increase in electric resistance was observed at later ages of 91 days, compared to the early age result [64]. They believed the reason was the hydration progress that occurred in the later ages. The maximum electrical resistance was found in mixtures that contained 6% and 1.5% MS and nanosilica, respectively. In another experiment, Jalal et al. introduced a mixture containing 2% NS and 10% SF increased the electrical resistivity values considerably and the corrosion tend to become impossible [65].
Khaloo et al. [66], observed that the increment of replacement level of NS from 0.75% to 1.5% contributes to the enhancement of specimens’ electrical resistivity. Moreover, they showed that at w/b ratio of 0.35 and 0.3 finer NS outperformed coarser NS in terms of electrical resistivity, while at a low w/b ratio of 0.25 coarser NS were more successful in the enhancement of electrical resistivity. Fig. 9 shows the obtained results in their study. They attributed
this phenomenon to a higher probability of agglomeration of finer NS at low w/b ratios. They discussed that in addition to the effective role of NS in refining the pore structure, it helps to change the chemistry of the pore solution and reduce its conductivity. The accelerated pozzolanic reactions of NS, which consume Ca(OH)2, lead to a reduction of OH in pore solution, and thereby electrical resistivity will increase [67–69]. Similar results related to the improvement of electrical resistivity of concrete with partial replacement of cement by NS were reported by Palla et al. [70]. They found that 2% NS replacement for production of concrete with a w/b ratio of 0.25 would be the optimum level. Quercia et al. [46], showed that the addition of colloidal and powder NS improved the resistivity of SCC more than 50% compared to the control concrete. They observed that colloidal NS was slightly more successful in amelioration of SCC’s electrical resistivity in comparison to powder NS. This matter was attributed to the higher reactivity of colloidal NS, which makes the microstructure more compact.

sections.heading: 3.4. Water permeability
sections.text:
Ji [14] investigated the influence of NS on water permeability of concrete. For the control concrete that only consisted of fly ash, the average penetration depth of 146 mm was observed, while 3% addition of NS to the mixture reduced the average penetration depth to the value of 81 mm. He used the ESEM test for the water permeability, and it revealed that the microstructure of the NS concrete was more uniform and compact than that of the normal concrete. He confirmed that concrete with NS was stickier than normal concrete due to the larger specific surface area.
In another study, Ji evaluated the effects of NS on the concrete water permeability with changing the surface area size from 10 to 20 nm. He adjusted the plasticizer dosage to obtain the same slump time. The test results showed that NS reduce the water permeability of hardened concrete [14]. Shirgir et al. [71] also observed that 5% percent replacement of cement with NS could lead to 13% reduction of hydraulic permeability of porous concrete in comparison to the control sample. The cause can be explained with the absorption of Ca(OH)2 crystals by NS particles. Therefore, an inadequate amount of the Ca(OH)2 crystals make the ITZ and binding matrix denser. As a result, NS fills the voids of the C-S-H gel structure. Naji Givi et al. investigated the development of the permeability properties of binary blended concrete with NS particles. They admixed NS at 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2% of cement. The best improvement was especially found in using 2% of NS. The test results showed that the NS particles not only led to denser cement mortar but also changed the morphology of cement hydration products [72].
Du et al. [42] observed that 0.3% replacement of NS could reduce water penetration depth to the extent of 56%. The addition of 0.9% NS slightly increased water penetration depth at the age of 28 days in comparison to 0.3% replacement. This increment was attributed to the agglomeration of NS particles at 0.9% dosage, which prevented further reaction of NS particles with cement. It is important to note that at the age of 91 days, 0.9% replacement of NS outperformed 0.3% replacement. This matter implies ongoing a pozzolanic reaction of NS and its ability in the refinement of the microstructure. Quercia et al. [46] revealed that 3.8% addition of both colloidal and powder types of NS resulted in negligible water penetration depth of 3 ± 2 mm. 88.5% reduction in water penetration depth in comparison to control mixture was accredited to modification of microstructure in terms of interconnectivity of pores. Result of their work is demonstrated in Fig. 10.
Li et al. examined the effects of NS on permeability of ecoconcrete with a mercury porosimetry intrusion (MIP). Test results showed that the relative permeability and pores sizes decreased with NS addition (1%–2%) [73]. The amount of reduction in perme-
ability in concrete with 2% NS was double compared to fly ash samples. This improvement is due to uniformity of the microstructure.

sections.heading: 3.5. Shrinkage
sections.text:
Shrinkage occurs in almost every cementitious product because of contraction of total mass due to loss of moisture through the materials. The most reported effect of NS is the impact on the durability properties of concrete. The NS properties depend on nature of the production method (colloidal or dry powder). Although the beneficial effects are reported for NS, its concentration level should be controlled. Shrinkage in the cementitious matrix is the major reason for cracks that impact durability. Robertson [74] found using NS in concrete containing pozzolan can reduce autogenous shrinkage of cement paste by about 46% compared to the control paste. However, ordinary mortars containing NS displayed higher drying shrinkage rather than the control mortar. This consequence was much more significant for a higher NS incorporation. It can be prevented by cautiously adding superplasticizer and suitable curing practices [75,76]. At high NS concentrations, the autogenous shrinkage due to self-desiccation increases, resulting in a higher cracking potential [77]. To prevent this adverse effect, high concentration levels of superplasticizer and water should be incorporated under proper curing conditions [67,75,78].
Sadrmomtazi et al. [15] studied the effects of adding NS and SF on shrinkage of self-compacted concrete. They reported that both NS and SF caused higher shrinkage in comparison to the control sample. Specimens made up of NS experienced the highest shrinkage. However, an obvious distinction was observed after about seven days. An increase in the shrinkage value of specimens made with NS mainly refer to the accelerated hydration process which increased hydration degree and as a result caused enhancement in chemical shrinkage. They also mentioned that the extent of shrinkage increased with replacement level of NS. Senff et al. also compared the addition of NS and SF on unrestrained shrinkage. They reported that the NS incorporation effects on the shrinkage did not follow a linear regression model. After 7 days the shrinkage increased 80%, while at 28 days it increased 54% (the maximum unrestrained shrinkages). They tried 1.75%, 3.5% and 7% NS as the replacement level percentages [76]. Fig. 11 shows unrestrained shrinkage of mortar with different dosage of NS in their work. The higher shrinkage level of NS can be attributed to the capability in refining the porous media. However, groups of researchers affirmed that nanoparticles enhance the mechanical performance and reduce the permeability and shrinkage [79,80].
Haruehansapong et al. [81] studied the effect of 9% NS replacement with particle sizes of 40, 20, and 12 nm on drying shrinkage of cement mortar. They observed that cement mortar made up of NS with average particle size of 12 and 20 nm undergo higher
drying shrinkage in comparison to control specimen and sample made with NS with average particle size of 40 nm. They discussed that this happened because NS with lower particle sizes has a greater tendency for accelerating pozzolanic reactions and contributed to a higher degree of hydration which led to a high shrinkage. Another reason that can be considered is that the distance between nanoparticles decreases with increasing content of nanoparticles. In that case, the Ca(OH)2 crystal has limited space to grow. Thus, the crystal quantity will be decreased that keeps the ratio of crystal to strengthening gel being small and the shrinkage increased [33].

sections.heading: 3.6. Frost resistance
sections.text:
In winter time, the temperature usually reaches subzero in cold regions. This reduction in temperatures causes problems for serval constructions in industry due to expansive ice formation in watersaturated pores. Internal stresses are induced by expansion pressures of ice, and if it exceeds the tensile strength of concrete, the concrete starts cracking until complete failure by excessive freezing-thawing cycles. In order to control the environmental impacts, improving the frost resistance of concrete mixtures is recommended by many agencies. Controlling the water-to-cement ratio, using an air entrainment admixture, improving the compactness, decreasing the porosity of concrete and modifying the internal voids of construction are suggested methods to improve the frost resistance. Incorporation of NS particles in concrete is an acceptable solution for enhancing the frost resistance of concrete.
Quercia et al. [46] studied the influence of powder and aqueous NS on freeze and thaw resistance of self-compacting concrete. They observed that aqueous NS was more successful in the improvement of frost resistance of self-compacting concrete with respect to control sample. They attributed this improvement to the formation of stiff C-S-H gel and refinement of pore structure, which prevents intrusion of water to concrete’s microstructure. Moreover, they mentioned that an addition of air entrainment admixture, which ensures 4% air content in the mixture in the presence of NS could result in high resistance concrete to freeze-thaw cycles.
Zhao et al. [82] studied the effects of different replacement percentages of NS on the frost resistance of concrete. They reported that NS decreased the capillary voids in the hardened concrete samples, and thus, the ability of concrete to be durable against the freezing-thawing cycles was developed by adding NS. Moreover, mixtures with the air-entraining agent had more freezingthawing cycle numbers. The closed bubbles caused by airentraining agent added in cement concrete can block the penetration channel in capillary and buffer static water pressure due to
water freeze, further changing the internal voids structure. Compared with ordinary concrete, the frost resistance of NS concrete and air-entraining agent concrete will increase by 28% and 42% [82]. They also found when water-to-cement-ratio is 0.35–0.39, the ability of frost twisting is very high, but when the water-tocement ratio is larger than 0.39, freezing-thawing resisting performance had a considerable decline. Salemi and Behfarnia [83] reported that 5% NS dosage addition to concrete enhanced the frost resistance by about 83%. In addition, they found that the combined mixture of fiber and NS has shown more frost resistance compared with the single addition of NS. The concrete with 0.2% polypropylene fiber (by the volume of concrete) had the best frost resistance. The authors discussed the mechanism of NS in improving concrete frost resistance, and concluded that the NS has the ability to restrict the growth of CH crystals in favor of supplying more CHS, which makes the concrete matrix more compact and homogeneous. Fig. 12 illustrates the effect of NS on the compressive strength of the concrete specimens after 50, 150 and 300 freezing-thawing cycles.

sections.heading: 3.7. Sulfate resistance
sections.text:
Sulfate resistance of concrete is the ability of concrete to resist the secondary ettringite formation due to later reaction of sulfate ions with hydrated aluminate phases. The secondary ettringite formation is an expansive reaction that can damage the concrete matrix. Concrete permeability plays a major role in sulfate resistance. Therefore, the NS can be used to reduce concrete permeability through refining the pore structure due to the ability of NS particles to work as internal filler within the concrete matrix. Arel and Thomas [85] investigated the effectiveness of NS and MS as a partial replacement of cement against sulfate attacks. Their mortar mixtures were prepared with a w/c ratio of 0.5 and exposed to 7% sodium sulfate solution over a duration of 23 weeks. They concluded that NS with a replacement of 8% is enough to make concrete highly resistance against external sulfate attacks. The authors also stated that the advantage of using NS over MS is the ability of NS materials to enhance the physical adherence in the aggregate-cement interface, which leads to an excessive reduction in the total porosity, thereby reduce the permeability of chemical species into concrete. A similar conclusion has been made by Moslemi et al. [86] on the investigation of the resistance of mortar against sulfate attack. Their results emphasized that 8% NS replacement of cement would be sufficient to improve the sulfate resistance of concrete. Tobón et al. [52] argue that 3% NS addition may lead to reduction of expansion up to 63% in comparison to control specimen, implying that smaller replacement level of NS may be effective in enhancing concrete resistance to sulfate.
Fig. 13 is drawn based on Tobón et al. result and reveals expansion of mortar exposed to 5% MgSO4 solution in this study [52]. This is also supported by a study conducted by Atahan and Dikme [87] where they reported that even 2% replacement of cement by NS would be enough for effectively controlling expansion due to sulfate attack. They both discussed that NS helps in refining the concrete pore system through increasing the smaller pores (gel pores) and reducing the connected pores (capillary pores), which significantly enhances the durability of concrete. As a result, aggressive agents of MgSO4 cannot penetrate into the cementitious matrix to produce expansive products. Ghafoori et al. [88], emphasized that the permeability modification of concrete is more important than controlling C3A content for preventing concrete expansion. They observed that mortars made with MS outperformed mortars made with powder NS in terms of resistance to sulfate attack. Agglomeration of these fine particles is the main reason for the inferior performance of powder NS. In contrast, aqueous NS with equal replacement level to MS was significantly more beneficial in expansion reduction of mortars subjected to sulfate attack.

sections.heading: 3.8. Carbonation resistance
sections.text:
Carbonation of concrete is the result of CO2 ingress through the concrete pores to disassociate the C-S-H and/or to chemically react with CH, forming new product, known as (calcium carbonate, CaCO3). This process can reduce the pH of the concrete as well as increase its porosity due to a replacement of relativity large CH molecules with smaller CaCO3 molecules, which can weaken the concrete matrix and significantly decrease its strength. The carbonation resistance of concrete depends on the pore system, the water to binder ratio, degree of hydration, and other factor concerning the exposure condition, including relative humidity and CO2 concentration. The contribution of NS to improve the carbonation resistance of concrete is a subject of debate. Some studies indicate that NS can positively affect the concrete resistance to carbonation while others indicates it may have negative effects. Lim and Mondal [89] studied the influence of NS and MS on the carbonation of bulk and powder cement paste samples exposed to an accelerated carbonation. They observed that powder samples had much greater carbonation than that for bulk (solid) samples. This was attributed due to the higher surface area of the powder sample that allows for more reactions with CO2, which is independent on the permeability. It was also shown that the pH value plays an important role in the carbonation kinetics through accelerating the rate in which the carbon dioxide binds with the hydroxyl ions to form carbonate ions, which in turns can react with CH to form calcium carbonate. Therefore, they concluded that the reduction of concrete carbonation depends not only on the permeability, but also on the pH of the pore solution. They also observed that a small
replacement of NS causes a reduction in the content of calcium hydroxide, thereby leading to a reduction in total carbonation. They eventually believe that MS and NS were both progressively successful in the reduction of carbonation depth. Li et al. also emphasize that [90] the addition of NS and MS can be helpful in reducing the carbonation of concrete, with a better performance of the simultaneous addition of both NS and MS to the mixture. Their results showed that 10% MS reduced carbonation depth by 33% more than that of 1% NS replacement. They discussed that the small volume of NS could not have a filling effect as effective as a high-volume of MS. Therefore, in combination state of NS and MS, MS will fill the voids among cement grains, and NS would fill the pores between the MS and cement grains. Result of this study is plotted in Fig. 14. On the other hand, Isfahani et al. [91] came to a different conclusion that the effects of different dosages of NS on the carbonation resistance of concrete made with different w/b ratios. The authors observed that the carbonation resistance of concrete was not affected by increasing NS dosages for concrete with w/b = 0.65 and 0.50, while the addition of similar dosage of NS in concrete with w/b = 0.55 slightly improved the carbonation resistance of concrete. They moreover noted that for w/b ratio of 0.65, the addition of NS can result in an adverse effect, possibly due to excessive moisture accompanied with increased porosity that can increase the diffusion rate of CO2. They concluded that NS addition may have negative effects on the capability of concrete to resist carbonation, unlike the w/b ratio which plays a major role in improving concrete resistance to carbonation. Rao et al. [92] also came to a similar conclusion that NS materials may not improve the carbonation resistance of concrete. They believe that use to the fact that the NS can form more C-S-H through pozzolanic reactions, the susceptibility of concrete to the carbonation attack will increase due to the possible carbonation of C-S-H phase if the CH is depleted.

sections.heading: 4. Pore structure and porosity
sections.text:
It is widely accepted that the pozzolanic and filler effects of NS can enhance the microstructure properties of concrete through reducing the porosity and improving the pore structure. However, it seems that the content of NS significantly influences its pozzolanic and filler effects. Said et al. [41] investigated the effect of colloidal NS on concrete pore structure. They used dosages of 0%, 3%, and 6% by total mass of cement. The w/b ratio of 0.40 was kept constant for all the mixtures. Their results showed that the addition of 6% colloidal NS could help in reducing the critical pores up to 40% as well as increasing the percentage of micro-pores by 4%. This was mainly attributed to the pozzolanic and filler effects of NS particles. The authors concluded that the total porosity and the critical pore were significantly decreases by increasing the dosage of NS. A similar conclusion has been made by Tobón et al. where they discussed the effect of colloidal NS on the porosity
and the pore structures for mortar specimens. The w/c ratio of the mortars was 0.4, and the NS dosages were 0, 5, 10% by weight of cement. Their results showed that 5% replacement of NS was not sufficient to alter the porosity and the pore structures of the mortar whereas 10% replacement of NS achieved 12% reduction in total porosity and produced a significant refinement of pores with respect to the reference sample. The authors concluded that incorporating of 10% NS could reduce the permeability of the paste matrix, thereby make it more resistant to chemical attacks. Oltulu and Sahin [93] investigated the pore structures of cement mortars produced by the addition of SF and containing NS powder at three different proportions of 0.5%, 1.25% and 2.5%. The results showed that mortars containing 0.5% and 1.25% NS reduced the pore volume and overall porosity relative to the control sample by 45% and 48%, respectively. However, mortars containing 2.5% NS increased the pore volume and overall porosity by 43%. They stated that the addition of NS to mortars dramatically changed the pore distribution due to the effect of nano filler that could decrease the pores in the range 10–100 nm. The authors concluded that the addition of the NS at proportions in excess of 1.25% could result in an increase in the pore volume of mortars because of agglomeration. Du et al. [42] argues that a small dosage of 0.9% NS in slurry form cannot alter the total porosity on concrete but it may improve the concrete pore structure. They observed that the total porosity of the reference sample and sample containing 0.9% NS was almost identical at about 13.5%. However, they noted that the concrete pore structure has improved by reducing large capillary pores (greater than50 nm) about 15% and increasing medium capillary pores (10–50 nm) about 32% comparing to the reference sample. The authors pointed out that the refinement on the large capillary pore was the result of the pozzolanic reaction as well as the ability of NS particles to work as a filler into the capillary pore structures. Fig. 15 illustrates Du et al. results [42]. Quercia et al. [46] studied the effect of incorporating 3.8% NS in colloidal and powder forms on the pore size distribution and the porosity the concrete. They observed that the addition of both colloidal and powder NS let to a reduction in the average pore diameter up to 12.5% and 6.8% with respect to the reference sample, respectively. Their results showed that NS materials made the pore structure of the cementitious matrix more homogeneous by increasing medium capillary pores (10–50 nm) and decreasing gel pores (<10 nm).
Joshaghani and Moeini tested influences of nanosilica and sugar cane bagasse ash (SCBA) on the mechanical and durability properties of mortar. They reported that the MIP test results showed that additives decreased the total specific pore volume of the mixtures. However, the effectiveness of nanosilica in improving the pore structure is better than SCBA, since the total amount of the harm-
less pores in mixtures containing nanosilica was increased to the largest extent. In addition, ternary blended mortar mixtures had better performance in total specific pore volume reduction [94].

sections.heading: 5. Fresh properties
sections.text:
Based on the previous experiments, a high-quality concrete mix has acceptable workability (about 60–70 mm slump height) in the fresh condition. The higher the measured slump flow, the better the workability will be, representing that the concrete flows quickly but at the same time is free from segregation [95,96]. NS modifies the characteristics of fresh mortars. The accelerating effect of NS incorporation in concrete was measured indirectly by rheological tests (viscosity change) of cement pastes and mortars [76,97]. In the fresh cement paste, a layer of adsorbed water molecules surround the fine particles. The reason is attributed to a decrease in the available amount of lubricating water in the mixture. Thus, an additional amount of water is required to fill the remaining void fraction of the granular system [98]. The fine powders mainly contribute to the total specific surface area and have the strongest effect on the total water demand of concrete mixtures. As a result, the powders may have a rather high water demand [98]. Hence, a suitable determination of the water amount is needed to cover all particles with a water layer of a certain thickness. Brouwers and Radix [99], Hunger and Brouwers [100], and Hunger [101] found a relationship between the specific surface area and the water demand of micro powder using the mini spread-flow test. They found a constant water layer (about 25 nm) for several tested powders. Researchers have reported effects of NS on the workability of cement paste by using rheometric measurements in the literature; however, the effects on the water demand by using the mini spread-flow test have not been reported widely [98].
The effect of NS on the workability of concrete can be measured regarding slump loss, according to ASTM C143 [102]. The viscosity measurements indicated that NS addition increased the need of water to keep the workability constant. Although rheometric methods are accurate, they might be time-consuming and difficult to conduct compared with standard workability tests [103,104]. Senff et al. reported that the yield stress, as a rheological parameter, is increased significantly by adding NS in the paste. The NS incorporation reduces the spread diameter on the flow table because of having more cohesiveness. They stated that the relationship between spread and yield stress values will justify the NS incorporation in the fresh properties [105]. Supit and Shaikh [106] showed that the addition of NS in concrete significantly decreased the slump loss up to 60% for NS level of 2–4%. The reason was attributed to the large specific surface area that adsorbedmore water from concrete mixtures [106]. A group of researchers reported that the proper percentage of NS should be small (1–5%) due to possible agglomeration induced by lack of particles dispersion [13,107,108]; however, some believe that the a better performance can also be achieved with higher dosages (10%). Besides, the size of NS particles is crucial in the fresh properties.
Sadrmomtazi et al. [15] indicated that incorporating NS in concrete generally made the samples more viscous. In conducting the workability tests, the authors did not observe any segregation or blockage. Quercia and Brouwers [77] tested the viscosity and found that using NS in cement paste and mortar samples requires more water to keep the workability of the mixtures constant. Moreover, it was reported that using NS caused a stronger tendency for adsorption of ionic species in the aqueous medium and the formation of agglomerates. Sari et al. [109] used colloidal NS (2%) to produce high-performance concrete with anti-bleeding properties and high workability. It seems that the colloidal particles of amorphous
silica appear to significantly influence the process of C3S hydration [75].
One of the applications of NS is using it in the rehabilitation jobs as a mortar. The water/powder (cement, nanoparticles, etc.) ratio of mortar and chemical admixtures should be tested to place the fresh mortar with no compaction and segregation [110]. Nazari et al. [111] checked the rheology of paste phase of self-repairing mortar and found that nanoparticles blended mixtures had low slump values and non-acceptable workability. The reason was attributed to the high surface area of powder after adding nanoparticles that needs more water for wetting the cement particles. Also, NS decreases the setting time of mortar compared with SF and makes cement paste thicker . Moreover, NS reduces segregation and bleeding water, and it will result in a higher cohesiveness state.

sections.heading: 6. Microstructure
sections.text:
Considering the chemical properties of NS particles, it has been reported that the NS used free lime (C-H) during hydration reactions. The result of this process is C-S-H gel formation due to the high fineness of NS particles [112]. The size of NS particles is about 1–100 nm, which is mainly advantageous in taking part in reactions as a nucleus. The results will be a dense cement hydrate products and an improved ITZ, even in low replacement levels [113]. Some researchers found that concrete samples containing NS have better performance compared to concrete that contains SF [114].
The durability properties of concrete can be measured through permeability. NS influences chemical and physical properties of concrete. The silica pozzolanic reaction with calcium hydroxide produces more C-S-H gels. Based on physical aspects, NS is about 100 times smaller than cement particles, is able to fill remaining voids in cement paste, and increases the final density of concrete at initial ages [78,115]. Using different electronic microscope techniques (SEM, ESEM, and TEM) to conduct microstructural analyses of concrete showed that the microstructure of concrete with NS is more uniform and dense than concrete without NS [14,75,76]. Using NS can improve the microscope properties of concrete due to the interface, surface and filler effects of nanoparticles [116]. The NS can act as an activator that enhances the hydration reactions of concrete and forms large amounts of C-S-H gel [32,53,117,118]. Thus, NS incorporation reduces the calcium leaching rate of cement pastes and increases durability [107,119]. Said et al. [41] examined the NS effects on the filler and pozzolanic reactions through thermal and microstructural tests. The concrete pore structure with NS was improved due to the nucleation effect of nanoparticles. Lin et al. [120] found the relative permeability and pore sizes of mixtures decreased with NS addition (1–2%) by using a mercury porosimetry test.
Ji [14] observed that concrete with NS showed more a compact and uniform microstructure compared with the control sample by SEM tests. The reason is attributed to the size Ca(OH)2 crystals that can be absorbed by NS and resulted in a denser ITZ of the cementitious matrix [30,72]. Givi et al. [1] emphasized that curing concrete samples in the lime solution can increase the pozzolanic activity and form more C-S-H gels in the presence of NS. Zhang and Islam [114] found that using SiO2 nanoparticles in the concrete led to a decrease in the porosity of the cement paste. Du et al. [42] reported the same results and believed that using NS caused the microstructure in ITZ to be more homogeneous due to the pozzolanic reaction and filler effects.
Shaikh and Sarker [121] reported that the microstructure of the concrete was perceptibly improved by using fly ash and NS with observing backscattered electron (BSE) images analysis and X-ray
diffraction (XRD) analysis. The secondary C-S-H gel can be formed to fill the micro-pores due to the tiny particle size and large specific surface area of NS. However, Supivt and Shaikh [106] observed that NS reacted more rapidly with the free lime in the hydration reactions than fly ash. In another study, decreasing permeability of concrete occurred while using NS, and high fly ash content (50%) was reported [73]. Ji [14] studied the effect of sizes of NS (10–20 nm) on concrete water permeability and microstructure. The test results showed that finer NS can improve the microstructure and reduce the water permeability of hardened concrete. Khaloo et al. [66] evaluated the microstructure of concrete samples containing assorted sizes of NS by using the SEM, XRD and mercury intrusion porosimetry tests. The results showed that the coarser NS was associated with a lower pozzolanic reactivity and a smaller acceleration of cement hydration compared the finer nanoparticles. In addition, the NS with coarser size had a better contribution in compacting cement matrix due to the preventing agglomerates of nanoparticles. Also, Givi et al. [1] observed the dense C-S-H gel (with the particle size of 15 nm) around NS particles (with the particle size of 80 nm) at early stages. Bani Ardalan et al. studied the effects of NS particles on concrete permeability through using the technique of spraying nanosilicon and treatment in the water-diluted NS oxide [122]. They found a denser microstructure was observed in the SEM images of samples cured in colloidal NS and sprayed with nanosilica. The densification of the microstructure can be attributed to the formation of the additional C-S-H gel.
Qing et al. [107] compared the effects of NS and SF. The consumption of C-H (crystals) content at the interface between the glass plate and the paste containing NS can be verified approximately by intensity changes of main diffraction peaks of C-H crystals, such as (0 0 1) crystal face, as well as (1 0 0) and (1 0 1), neglecting the effect of orientation on the intensity. Diffraction peak intensities of the (1 0 0) and (1 0 1) crystal faces of C-H at the interface of sample 3% NS replacement were almost equal to those of the control sample, but the intensity of the (0 0 1) crystal face was much less than that of the control sample. For example, as compared with the control sample, the intensities of the (0 0 1) crystal face at the interface of the sample with 3% NS decreased by 67%, 61% and 64% at ages of 1 day, 7 days and 28 days, respectively.

sections.heading: 7. Nano-silica challenges
sections.text:
Nanoparticles have a large surface area to volume ratio, which provides considerable potential for further reactions. However, one of the main problems regarding the usage of nanoparticles and especially NS is their agglomeration due to their high surface area and great surface attraction force among the particles [123]. Indeed, in the agglomerated state, NS particle size will change to the micron range. Therefore, their effective role in providing nucleation sites in pozzolanic reactions or their filler effect for densification of the porous concrete structure will be limited [72,124]. As a result, well-dispersion of NS in concrete or mortar is a challenge that many researchers have tried to deal with. There are different types of NS materials, which can lead to different results in the fresh and hardened properties of concrete due to their dispersion. Pyrogenic NS (powder form) and NS hydrosol (colloidal suspension) are common types of NS that were used by researchers in a cementitious matrix. The first type is usually in a state of agglomerated particles, and their dispersion in water is complicated. In contrast, NS particles in a hydrosol state are insoluble and monodispersed in water [124,125]. However, previous researchers demonstrated that colloidal NS also would be coagulated after addition to cement, owing to the enhancement of the paste’s ionic strength [126]. Amiri et al. [127] investigated the influence of pH values on the dispersion of pyrogenic NS with an average size of
12 nm. Their research revealed that an increase of pH values, which was followed by five minutes of high shear mixing of diluted NS suspension and 60 min sonication, can be helpful in deagglomeration of nanoparticles up to the size of 0.2 mm. Bagheri et al. [123] were also successful in breaking the agglomerated particles of pyrogenic NS up to an average size of 0.045 mm by applying 60 min of sonication and adjusting the pH value of suspension to 10.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions
sections.text:
This review paper studies the fresh, mechanical, durability, and microstructural properties of modified concrete with NS. Providing a nucleation site for further reactions, accelerating pozzolanic reactions, filling the pores in the microstructure, and producing more C-S-H gel that refines the microstructure are the main effective performances of NS in improving concrete’s properties. However, difficulties in working with NS, which mainly refer to its tendency to agglomerate, should not be disregarded. Based on the review of a hundred papers, the following conclusions can be drawn:
1. The addition of NS to concrete contributes to the enhancement of compressive strength due to the production of CS-H gel and densification of the microstructure. Different thresholds have been proposed by researchers for optimal replacement of NS. However, most of the proposed thresholds are less than 5% replacement. Addition of any content more than that of the optimal level to the mixture causes reduction of compressive strength due to agglomeration of nano particles. 2. Tensile and flexural strength follow a similar trend of compressive strength increment with the addition of NS to the mixture. The improvement in bonding between the aggregate and the matrix can be considered for enhancement of flexural and tensile strength. Moreover, NS shows a good synergetic effect with other materials, such as fiber and nano clay. 3. The abrasion resistance of concrete ameliorates by replacing cement with NS. It is found that abrasion resistance of concrete depends on its pore structure, which can be improved by the addition of NS to the mixture. A small dosage incorporation of NS could enhance the surface index of abrasion resistant to a great extent. Moreover, the abrasion resistance of concrete enhances with the increase of compressive strength. 4. With the incorporation of NS, the compressive loss due to the exposure to high temperature could improve obviously. Formation of the secondary gel by incorporation of NS, which makes the microstructure denser, can exclude propagation of cracks at elevated temperature. Addition of NS leads to a higher compressive and flexural strength of concrete at elevated temperature in comparison to the control sample. 5. The incorporation of NS lead to the reduction of chloride ions penetration. NS refines the pore structure of concrete and more importantly lead to the reduction of prosity at ITZ. Furthermore, by causing more tortuous and disconnected routes improve the permeability of concrete. It should be noted that NS with the very high specific surface area may not be as effective as coarse NS. Higher specific surface area can lead to a higher tendency for agglomeration of nano particles and formation of micro particles. As such, it is harder to work with a NS with higher specific surface area. 6. NS not only could be prominently effective at binary mixture but works progressively alongside other pozzolanic materi-
als, such as RHA. Filling empty pores with different sizes and rupture of connected pores are two of the reasons cause reduction in water absorption. 7. The addition of NS to cement matrix can improve the electrical resistivity of concrete not only by refinement of pore structure, but also by consuming of Ca(OH)2 and causing a reduction in OH content in pore solution thereby conductivity reduction of specimens. 8. Addition of a small dosage of NS could decrease water penetration depth to a great extent in comparison to control mixture. It should be noted that continuous pozzolanic reactions would yield the best results regarding the penetration depth at long-term ages. Refinement of pore structure and filler effect of NS are responsible for the observed reduction in water penetration depth. 9. The incorporation of NS can increase the extent of shrinkage, and its value can enhance with the increment of NS replacement level. The growth of shrinkage mainly happens due to the fact that NS will lead to higher degree of hydration thereby higher chemical shrinkage. It should be noted that NS particle size has a great effect on shrinkage extent. The lower NS particles size, the higher extent of shrinkage would be. The reason is the higher reactivity of finer NS particles; therefore, consumption of greater amount of existing water in the mixture, as a result higher chemical shrinkage. 10. The addition of NS ameliorates frost resistance of concrete by refinement of pore structure and also by densification of the microstructure. Although NS can considerably enhance the resistance of concrete against freeze-thaw cycles, however air-entraining admixtures are highly recommended for improvement of frost resistance. 11. NS was significantly effective in improving sulfate resistance and causes notable expansion reduction in the samples. A small dosage addition of NS to the concrete mixture can cause negligible expansion of the samples after exposure to MgSO4. Moreover, great ability of NS in the improvement of ITZ lead to a desirable reduction in total porosity, and as a result preventing penetration of aggressive agents of sulfate ions into the concrete. 12. With the simultaneous incorporation of NS and MS, it was found that carbonation depth can reduce. Permeability reduction due to the production of secondary gel, filling effect of NS and MS, and reduction of pore solution pH attributed to carbonation depth reduction. In contrast, some researchers observed that carbonation coefficient was not influenced by the addition of NS to concrete and even carbonation depth can be increased in some cases. 13. NS has a substantial influence of on pore size distribution regarding its filler effect, which can decrease the number of pores in 10–100 nm range. In fact, the addition of NS refines the large capillary pores while filling the medium capillary pores. In other words, NS makes the pore size distribution more homogenous. Having a more homogenous microstructure cause a reduction in permeability. 14. Inclusion of NS particles in concrete decreases slump values and workability. For keeping the slump values equal to the control sample, more water is needed in mixtures. However, it should be mentioned that although the presence of NS in the mixture makes it more viscous, it can prevent segregation and blockage. 15. The addition of NS particles to the cement matrix can make the microstructure denser and more homogenous. Indeed, NS elevates cement hydration and reacts with free lime which leads to the formation of a great amount of C-S-H gel and as a result densification of the cement matrix. Fur-
thermore, NS can fill the micro-pores in the microstructure, also in ITZ, and reduce the porosity.
Conflict of interest
The authors declare that there is no conflict of interests.

metadata.abstractText: Long-term durability of concrete has been of interest for researchers in past decades, and throughout their numerous research endeavors, they have tried to improve durability with the application of different methods. One technique is the integration of a new material into the concrete. One material that has attracted great attention of researchers is nano-SiO2 (NS). Its considerable performance in the enhancement of durability properties of concrete and mortar provides reasonable specifications satisfaction for scholars. In this paper, important durability characteristics of concrete, including the chloride ion penetration, electrical resistivity, water penetration, water absorption, the pore size distribution, the carbonation, the sulfate resistance, frost resistance, shrinkage, and thermal properties were explored. Additionally, the effects on the microstructure of concrete and mortar in the previous studies were discussed. Mechanical properties, such as compressive strength, flexural strength, tensile strength, and abrasion resistivity were also investigated in the past and most recent papers. 2018 Elsevier Ltd.
